documentType: Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) claim form with addendum
summary: A Federal Tort Claims Act claim filed by attorneys Jennifer Freeman and the Marsh Law Firm on behalf of two claimants (redacted) and a class of Epstein victims, seeking $600 million in damages. The claim alleges the FBI negligently failed to act on a 1996 report of Epstein's sex trafficking conspiracy, enabling decades of abuse. It details the 1996 report, subsequent FBI failures, and Epstein's special treatment.

persons.name: Jennifer Freeman
persons.context: Listed as the claimant's representative from the Marsh Law Firm on the FTCA claim form.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the alleged sex trafficking conspiracy. The claim details his abuse of the claimants and others, and alleges the FBI's failure to investigate him.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's associate who helped traffic girls, created a 'modeling book,' and threatened victims alongside Epstein.

persons.name: Eric Fischl
persons.context: Mentor to one claimant (redacted) who advised her to flee Epstein's Ohio residence in 1996. Listed as a potential witness.

persons.name: Steven Hoffenberg
persons.context: Epstein worked with him at Towers Financial; Hoffenberg was prosecuted for a Ponzi scheme while Epstein faced no consequences.

persons.name: William Burns
persons.context: Mentioned as having three meetings scheduled with Epstein in 2014 when he was Deputy Secretary of State.

persons.name: Larry Nassar
persons.context: Cited as an example of the FBI's failure to investigate serious allegations, drawing a parallel to the Epstein case.

persons.name: Michael Reiter
persons.context: Listed as a potential witness with knowledge of investigations into Epstein.

persons.name: Sergey Brin
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the claim.

persons.name: Anne Wojcicki
persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the claim.

persons.context: Listed among individuals who may have relevant information pertaining to the claim.

persons.name: Detective Phelan
persons.context: Listed as NYPD personnel with knowledge of a 1996 report made to the NYPD.

persons.name: Nesbitt Kirkendall
persons.context: Listed as a current or former FBI agent with knowledge about investigations into the Epstein sex trafficking conspiracy.

connections.description: Described as working together to traffic girls, create a 'modeling book,' sexually abuse a claimant, and threaten victims.
Epstein worked with Hoffenberg at Towers Financial, which was involved in a major Ponzi scheme.
Epstein had three meetings scheduled with Burns in 2014, according to calendar entries.
Indirect connection; Fischl was the mentor of a claimant who was abused by Maxwell and Epstein.

events.title: 1996 FBI Report Filed
events.description: A claimant (redacted) reported Epstein and Maxwell's sex trafficking conspiracy, sexual abuse, theft of photographs, and threats to the FBI. The FBI allegedly ignored the report.

events.title: Sexual Abuse in Ohio
events.description: Epstein and Maxwell sexually abused a claimant at Epstein's New Albany, Ohio residence and stole photographs, including of her 11-year-old sister.

events.title: Florida Federal Investigation and NPA
events.description: Federal law enforcement in Florida investigated Epstein, interviewed victims, but then entered into a secret non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with Epstein, resulting in a light jail sentence.

events.title: Trafficking of Second Claimant
events.description: A second claimant (redacted) was trafficked by Epstein and Maxwell in the Virgin Islands, New York, and elsewhere during the time of the Florida investigation.

events.title: Federal Prosecution of Epstein and Maxwell
events.description: The federal government finally prosecuted Epstein and later Maxwell for sex trafficking conspiracy.

events.title: Court Protocol for CSAM Review
events.description: In ongoing litigation, Epstein's Estate alerted the court to possible Child Sex Abuse Material (CSAM) among discovered media, leading to a court-ordered FBI review protocol.

locations: 935 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW Washington, D.C. 20535-0001 (FBI Headquarters)
New York City (Epstein's residence and offices)
East 66th Street, New York City (apartment building)
keyFacts: A claimant reported Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell's sex trafficking conspiracy, sexual abuse, and possible child pornography production to the FBI on August 29, 1996, but the FBI took no action.

The FTCA claim seeks $600 million in damages on behalf of two named claimants and a class of all Epstein victims trafficked after August 29, 1996, alleging the FBI's negligence enabled decades of abuse.
The claim alleges the FBI failed to investigate multiple times, including ignoring the 1996 report and later truncating a 2008 investigation into child erotica found in Epstein's home.

The document presents circumstantial evidence that Epstein received special treatment, possibly due to being a government informant, citing his connections to high-level officials and avoidance of prosecution in earlier scandals.
The claim lists numerous potential witnesses, including victims, law enforcement officials, and high-profile individuals like Sergey Brin and Anne Wojcicki.
